structured_info.title_cn: 主成分分析在入侵检测系统中使用不同支持向量机核的性能研究
structured_info.title_en: Performance Investigation of Principal Component Analysis for Intrusion Detection System Using Different Support Vector Machine Kernels
structured_info.abstract: The growing number of security threats has prompted the use of a variety of security techniques. The most common security tools for identifying and tracking intruders across diverse network domains are intrusion detection systems. Machine Learning classifiers have begun to be used in the detection of threats, thus increasing the intrusion detection systems' performance. In this paper, the investigation model for an intrusion detection systems model based on the Principal Component Analysis feature selection technique and a different Support Vector Machine kernels classifier is present. The impact of various kernel functions used in Support Vector Machines, namely linear, polynomial, Gaussian radial basis function, and Sigmoid, is investigated. The performance of the investigation model is measured in terms of detection accuracy, True Positive, True Negative, Precision, Sensitivity, and F-measure to choose an appropriate kernel function for the Support Vector Machine. The investigation model was examined and evaluated using the KDD Cup 99 and UNSW-NB15 datasets. The obtained results prove that the Gaussian radial basis function kernel is superior to the linear, polynomial, and sigmoid kernels in both used datasets. Obtained accuracy, Sensitivity, and F-measure of the Gaussian radial basis function kernel for KDD CUP 99 were 99.11%, 98.97%, and 99.03%. For UNSW-NB15 datasets were 93.94%, 93.23%, and 94.44%.
structured_info.methodology: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for feature selection and Support Vector Machine (SVM) with four kernel functions (linear, polynomial, Gaussian radial basis function, sigmoid) for classification. Evaluated using KDD Cup 99 and UNSW-NB15 datasets with performance metrics including accuracy, precision, sensitivity, and F-measure.
structured_info.conclusion: The Gaussian radial basis function (RBF) kernel outperformed linear, polynomial, and sigmoid kernels in both datasets. For KDD Cup 99, RBF achieved 99.11% accuracy, 98.97% sensitivity, and 99.03% F-measure. For UNSW-NB15, RBF achieved 93.94% accuracy, 93.23% sensitivity, and 94.44% F-measure.

analysis.Overview: The paper investigates the performance of PCA-based feature selection combined with SVM classifiers using different kernels (linear, polynomial, RBF, sigmoid) for intrusion detection systems. Evaluated on KDD Cup 99 and UNSW-NB15 datasets.
Background_and_Motivation: Increasing cyber threats and limitations of traditional security tools like firewalls necessitate advanced intrusion detection systems.
To enhance IDS efficiency by reducing features via PCA and identifying the optimal SVM kernel for attack classification.
Authors highlight the urgency due to evolving attack complexity and the critical role of IDS as a security layer.
The specific problem of kernel selection is framed within the broader challenge of improving network security against sophisticated threats.
Contributes to machine learning, network security, and data mining disciplines.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: PCA: Dimensionality reduction technique preserving critical data features. SVM: Classifier using kernel functions for non-linear data separation. Kernel Functions: Mathematical transforms enabling SVM to handle complex data.
PCA reduces dataset features; processed data is classified by SVM kernels to distinguish normal/attack traffic.
Assumes PCA effectively retains essential information after reduction, and SVM kernels can generalize well on reduced datasets.
Provides empirical validation of kernel performance in IDS, establishing RBF as superior for PCA-processed data.
Methodology: PCA for feature reduction, SVM with four kernels for classification. Python scikit-learn implementation with train-test splits (80-20).
Novelty lies in comparative kernel analysis with PCA. Applicable to IDS; rational due to PCA's efficiency and SVM's classification strength.

KDD Cup 99 (42 features) and UNSW-NB15 (45 features). Preprocessing: cleaning (missing values, outlier removal), normalization. Datasets represent historical/modern attacks but lack newer threats like phishing.
Rigorous design: confusion matrix metrics (accuracy, precision, sensitivity, F-measure). Adequate evaluation across two datasets.
Follows supervised ML paradigm, focusing on empirical validation rather than theoretical innovation.
Results: RBF kernel achieved highest accuracy (99.11% on KDD Cup 99; 93.94% on UNSW-NB15), sensitivity (98.97%; 93.23%), and F-measure (99.03%; 94.44%). Sigmoid performed worst.
Results are significant due to consistency across datasets/metrics. Reliability strengthened by using standard datasets and multiple performance measures.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Structured as: problem motivation → methodology → experimental results → conclusion.
Steps: Motivate PCA-SVM integration → evaluate kernels → demonstrate RBF superiority → validate with metrics. Logical flow from data preprocessing to performance comparison.
Strengths: Clear empirical validation. Weaknesses: Limited to two datasets/kernels. Addressed rebuttals by comparing with prior works in Table 3.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: High accuracy with RBF kernel; PCA reduces computational complexity; comprehensive metrics.
Limitations: Excludes modern attacks (e.g., DDoS, phishing); relies on SVM without hybrid approaches; dataset constraints.
Theoretical focus on PCA-SVM limits exploration of alternative ML paradigms (e.g., deep learning).
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions within ML-for-security discourse by optimizing established techniques (PCA-SVM) rather than introducing new models.
Technical terminology (e.g., kernels, dimensionality reduction); persuasive rhetoric through tables/figures; authoritative tone via citations.
Builds credibility by referencing 36 prior works; citation motivations include contextualizing methods and benchmarking results.
Conclusions_and_Implications: RBF kernel is optimal for PCA-enhanced IDS. Sigmoid is ineffective.
Future work: Test modern datasets; develop new kernels; explore alternative feature-reduction techniques beyond PCA.
